timeline.subject: Claude Pieton
timeline.details: Claude Pieton of Bathelemont was executed at Parroy as a witch, and maintained his accusation that he had seen Babillon four times at the sabbat, where unlike others she wore no mask

timeline.subject: Babillon femme Claudon Girard
timeline.details: C.M. Rémy orders taking of evidence

timeline.subject: Babillon femme Claudon Girard
timeline.details: Informations preparatoires conducted with 71 witnesses over two days

timeline.subject: Babillon femme Claudon Girard
timeline.details: Substitut for procureur general asks for arrest and interrogation

timeline.subject: Babillon femme Claudon Girard
timeline.details: Substitut for procureur general asks for question ordinaire et extraordinaire

timeline.subject: Babillon femme Claudon Girard
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves question ordinaire only

timeline.subject: Babillon femme Claudon Girard
timeline.details: Interrogation under torture - withstood thumbscrews, confessed when racked, retracted, racked again, then promised to confess if taken from cell

timeline.subject: Babillon femme Claudon Girard
timeline.details: Interrogation following torture - gave detailed confession

timeline.subject: Babillon femme Claudon Girard
timeline.details: Substitut for PG asks for death sentence

timeline.subject: Babillon femme Claudon Girard
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves death sentence with proviso that she be strangled after feeling fire

prior_accusations.context: maintained at execution that he had seen Babillon four times at the sabbat, where unlike others she wore no mask

notable_quotes.speaker: Babillon to Catherine Pieton's son Bastien
notable_quotes.french: Bastien je suis bien aisé de ce que ton pere s'en est allé Il n'accusera pas personne
notable_quotes.english: Bastien I am very relieved that your father has gone away. He will not accuse anyone
notable_quotes.context: When Claude Pieton fled in fear of arrest

notable_quotes.speaker: Babillon to Catherine Pieton
notable_quotes.french: lors bon dieu mais qu'il n'accuse poinct de gens de bien
notable_quotes.english: then good God may he not accuse good people
notable_quotes.context: When Catherine told her she had spoken to her imprisoned husband

notable_quotes.speaker: Babillon to Girard Husson
notable_quotes.french: que les poulleur et camans estoient maire et que les bons bourgeois ne l'estoient
notable_quotes.english: that the dirty scoundrels were maire and that the good citizens were not
notable_quotes.context: Dispute over mairie position 9 years earlier

notable_quotes.speaker: Babillon to Margueritte femme Anthoine Epvre
notable_quotes.french: que l'on avoit pensé donner cela sur elle deposante mais parce qu'elle s'avait bien signée et qu'elle estoit bonne chrestienne l'on n'avoit eu puissance sur elle et partant l'on avoit donné cela a l'arbre
notable_quotes.english: that they had thought to give that to her [witness] but because she had crossed herself well and was a good Christian they had no power over her and therefore they gave it to the tree
notable_quotes.context: Explaining why plum tree died instead of witness

notable_quotes.speaker: Babillon to Mengeatte femme Barbellin Michel
notable_quotes.french: t'en garde tu ne seras pas tousjours sy haulte
notable_quotes.english: beware you will not always be so haughty

notable_quotes.speaker: Witness reply to Babillon
notable_quotes.french: taisez vous ne me menasse poinct l'on vous cognoit bien je suis de ceste ville et l'on vous cognoist bien
notable_quotes.english: be quiet don't threaten me they know you well I am from this town and they know you well

notable_quotes.speaker: Babillon to Pierron Joly
notable_quotes.french: qu'il n'en seroit guere plus riche
notable_quotes.english: that he would not be much richer for it

notable_quotes.speaker: Babillon during interrogation
notable_quotes.french: Je voudrois que le diable t'eust emporte, rompu le col, ou autrement
notable_quotes.english: I wish the devil had carried you off, broken your neck, or otherwise
notable_quotes.context: Admitting she used such threats in quarrels

notable_quotes.speaker: Babillon during interrogation
notable_quotes.french: qu'elle eust volontiers eu la puissance de ce faire, ayant beaucoup de peine d'endurer propos approchants ceste injure et qu'ell eust bien aimé que l'on luy eust dict haultement et publicquement pour avoir plus de moyen de se venger
notable_quotes.english: that she would gladly have had the power to do this, having much pain in enduring words approaching this injury and that she would have liked it said loudly and publicly to have more means to take revenge
notable_quotes.context: Admitting she wished for power to harm those who called her witch

notable_quotes.speaker: Babillon under torture
notable_quotes.french: gros et durs Crestiens de ne la vouloir croire en son dire
notable_quotes.english: great and hard Christians not to want to believe her in her words
notable_quotes.context: Calling judges harsh for not believing her denials

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon femme Didier Lorrique about father's death
notable_quotes.english: that he would take care of it/beware
notable_quotes.context: Babillon's words after quarrel with husband, week before father fell ill

notable_quotes.speaker: Babillon to Jennon femme Didier Lorrique
notable_quotes.english: that she would lower her crest/pride

relationships.evidence_text: daughter of Humbert Bourdon laboureur of Juvrecourt
daughter of Humbert Bourdon and his wife Alix
the Alix burned at Henamenil had been cousin of her mother
as her mother was cutting grass by the field, she was suddenly taken ill and died in 3 days
had heard her father Jean Girard
frere non germain of Babillon's husband
brother living at Ley also suspected
aunt living at Juvrecourt had been executed
her son Humbert had quarrelled with her and called her witch
Had asked witness and her sister to get some soup from Babillon

economic_context.details: Multiple economic conflicts: field rental disputes (witnesses 47, 48, 49, 67), cauldron seized over unpaid 'aide generale' (witness 71), land purchase/repurchase dispute (witness 66), loan of 6 gros refused (witness 42, 66), dispute over mairie position which had economic benefits (witnesses 15, 22). Witness 10 found her taking cherries from his tree but did not dare fine her. Cloth money dispute with Nicolas Bise.

devil offered purse of money but she refused

Nicolas Bise kept money when overpaid for some cloth

mist around top of plum tree
made clouds and mists at sabbat
economic_hardship_indicators: small loans of 6 gros being significant
economic value of animals (horses, cattle, foals) crucial to livelihoods

prior_legal_disputes.description: Mother Alix was 'injuriée' long ago by le gros Masson, who said she was a witch. Parents took him to court at Vic and he had to withdraw accusations
Jean Henriquel caught with pockets full of grain after threshing in their barn 20 years earlier
Land purchase/repurchase dispute with Nicolas Cabossel went to court
prior_legal_disputes.outcome: Husband agreed to allow repurchase of land after developing thigh trouble

legal_context.redress_outcome: Would have taken action against those who called her witch if she had witnesses; took no action against Nicolas Biche because there were no witnesses
legal_context.imprisonment_conditions: Imprisoned at Einville; after torture told goaler she wanted to confess if they would take her from place where she was

hearsay_chains.content: her mother had suspected Babillon of giving her a fatal illness
suspected Babillon of making her ill after refusing loan of 6 gros
believed Babillon had given her fatal illness
her mother thought Babillon had given her illness from which she died
she had called Babillon witch but took no action
son Claudon had said his mother had 'ung pot de pouldre caché en terre en ung meix'

emotional_state_notes: Called judges 'gros et durs Crestiens' during torture
Admitted she wished for power to harm those who called her witch
Initially resisted torture but eventually broke down

reproaches_to_witnesses.objection: Catherine Pieton was a liar; sister of Jean Mengin's wife had been executed as witch at Marsal
Marguerite Epvre was liar and suspected at Bauzemont just as she was
Jean Henriquel was a thief; 20 years earlier her husband had caught him with pockets full of grain
Mother of Gerard Toussains had no reason to fear her, they had been good friends and she had often confided in her
Heilleny femme Nicolas Fery had evil tongue and husband was thief

Mengeate femme Claudon Virion - girls at poisle had talked of seeing her fall from a cloud; if she was a witch this would have been evident when she served as midwife; mother had been wrong to suspect her; mother of Claudon Virion was suspected as she was
Claudon Paris and her sister were suspected of stealing shoes at fairs and markets
Bellatte Barbellin was a thief and had been caught stealing a sheet; brother and children were also reputed thieves
Aunt of Nicolle Pierson had been executed at Bauzemont and her mother had not dared to go there for fear she would accuse her
Didiere Marchal was her niece and mother had been her great friend, so she would not have hurt her

extraction_metadata.notes: Extremely well-documented trial with 71 witnesses over two days of informations preparatoires. Multiple family members executed as witches (mother Alix, aunt Alix, sister/cousin, another aunt). Strong reputation evidence spanning 20-36 years. Economic disputes prominent: mairie position, field rentals, debts, property boundaries. Accused initially resisted but confessed under torture, naming devil 'Vert Vestu' (Green Dressed). Pattern of harm-after-quarrel typical of witch trials. Executed 28 November 1610.
